title: How to Permanently Delete Your LinkedIn Account

steps.title: Cancel your LinkedIn Premium subscription (if you have one).
steps.content: Cancel your LinkedIn Premium subscription (if you have one). If you subscribe to LinkedIn Premium, you'll want to cancel your subscription before you can delete your account. [1] X Research source iPhone/iPad: Open your Settings app, tap your name, select “Subscriptions,” tap your LinkedIn subscription, and then tap “Cancel Subscription.” [2] X Research source Android: Hit “Premium features” beneath your profile picture, “Manage subscription” (from a drop-down menu that’s near “Subscription details” beneath “Premium Account and Features”), followed by “Manage subscription” and “Cancel subscription.” [3] X Research source

steps.title: Delete any LinkedIn Groups you own.
steps.content: Delete any LinkedIn Groups you own. If you are the owner of a LinkedIn group, you'll have to delete it before deleting your account. LinkedIn Groups can only be deleted when using LinkedIn on a computer. To delete a group on a computer: [4] X Research source Click Edit next to your group on LinkedIn. Click Delete this group and then click Delete this group again to confirm.

steps.title: Tap your profile photo on the LinkedIn app.
steps.content: Tap your profile photo on the LinkedIn app. You'll see it at the top of the screen. A menu will expand.

steps.title: Tap Settings and Account preferences.
steps.content: Tap Settings and Account preferences .

steps.title: Tap Close account.
steps.content: Tap Close account . You’ll find this in the “Account Management” section. Some information about closing your account will appear. If you still want to close your account, continue to the next step.

steps.title: Tap Continue.
steps.content: Tap Continue . This allows you to continue shutting down your account.

steps.title: Select a reason for closing your account and tap Next.
steps.content: Select a reason for closing your account and tap Next . You can also enter details about why you no longer want to participate in LinkedIn.

steps.title: Confirm your account password and tap Done.
steps.content: Confirm your account password and tap Done . This deactivates your LinkedIn account. If you log back in within 14 days of closing your account, your account will automatically reopen. [5] X Research source As long as you don't sign in again within 14 days of closing your account, your account will be permanently deleted. Deleting your account will permanently delete all endorsements, recommendations, invitations, followings, and group memberships, even if you decide to reactivate within 14 days.

steps.title: Cancel your Premium subscription (if you have one).
steps.content: Cancel your Premium subscription (if you have one). If you subscribe to LinkedIn Premium, you'll want to cancel your subscription before deleting your account. To cancel LinkedIn Premium: [6] X Research source Click the “Me” tab at the top and select “Access My Premium. Click “Premium features.” Hit “Subscription details.” Click “Manage subscriptions.” Click “Cancel subscription.”

steps.title: Close any groups you own.
steps.content: Close any groups you own. If you own a LinkedIn group, you will have to delete it before you can delete your account. To delete your group: [7] X Research source Go to your group in LinkedIn. Click “Edit” to the right of your group. Click “Delete this group” and then “Delete this group” again to confirm.

steps.title: Click the Me tab.
steps.content: Click the Me tab. It's the option with your profile photo at the top of the page. [8] X Research source A menu will expand. If your LinkedIn profile doesn't have a picture uploaded, this icon will be a silhouette of a person's head and shoulders.

steps.title: Click Settings & Privacy on the menu.
steps.content: Click Settings & Privacy on the menu.

steps.title: Click the Account preferences tab.
steps.content: Click the Account preferences tab. It's at the top of the left column.

steps.title: Scroll to the Account management section.
steps.content: Scroll to the Account management section. This option is at the bottom of the page.

steps.title: Click Close account.
steps.content: Click Close account . [9] X Research source

steps.title: Choose the reason for closing your account and hit Next.
steps.content: Choose the reason for closing your account and hit Next . You can type some details into the field if you'd like, but it's not required.

steps.title: Confirm your password and click Close account.
steps.content: Confirm your password and click Close account . This deactivates your LinkedIn account. If you log back in within 14 days of closing your account, your account will reactivate. [10] X Research source Deleting your account will permanently delete all endorsements, recommendations, invitations, followings, and group memberships, even if you decide to reactivate within 14 days.

steps.title: Log into your account within 14 days of shutting it down.
steps.content: Log into your account within 14 days of shutting it down. While your account is considered shut down after you’ve closed it, it’s still possible to reopen it within a 2-week window. Just use your original account info and hit “Sign In.” [11] X Research source Despite popular belief, you can’t reactivate your LinkedIn account after 20 days. At that point, you’ll have to make a new one. Alternative: Use the link embedded in your account closure email to log in and reboot your account.

steps.title: Hit Reactivate to reopen your account.
steps.content: Hit Reactivate to reopen your account. Keep in mind that your old groups, endorsements, followings, recommendations, and pending (or ignored) invitations will be completely inaccessible. Your old connections will still be available, though! [12] X Research source

steps.title: Click or tap here to put your account in hibernation.
steps.content: Click or tap here to put your account in hibernation. Hibernating your account essentially deactivates your account rather than shutting it down. If you don’t want to have your account up and running but also don’t want to delete it entirely, hibernating could be a good option for you. [13] X Research source Hibernating shuts down your LinkedIn Premium subscription, so you don’t need to worry about canceling it independently. Alternative: Head to “Settings & Privacy” followed by “Hibernate account,” which is under the “Account management” tab. Choose a reason for why you’re hibernating your account, submit your password, and then hit “Hibernate account” to put your account to sleep.
